message.content:
{
  "paper_metadata": {
    "doi": "10.1002/smj.167",
    "title": "GUANXI AND ORGANIZATIONAL DYNAMICS: ORGANIZATIONAL NETWORKING IN CHINESE FIRMS",
    "authors": [
      "Seung Ho Park",
      "Yadong Luo"
    ],
    "publication_year": 2001,
    "journal": "Strategic Management Journal",
    "research_type": "Quantitative",
    "research_context": "Survey of 128 firms across various industries in central China (Shanghai and Jiangsu), 1996–1997; examines antecedents and performance effects of guanxi under China’s transition economy",
    "is_replication_study": false
  },
  "constructs": [
    {
      "term": "guanxi",
      "definition": "Guanxi refers to drawing on a web of connections to secure favors in personal and organizational relations. It is an intricate, pervasive relational network with implicit mutual obligations, assurances, and understandings, operating through principles of transferability, reciprocity, intangibility, and utilitarian exchange rather than emotional attachment. Guanxi is rooted in Confucianism, linked to concepts such as face (mianzi) and renqing, and functions as social capital that curtails opportunism and facilitates exchanges in China’s uncertain, transition economy.",
      "context_snippet": "Guanxi is a cultural characteristic... drawing on a web of connections to secure favors... an intricate and pervasive relational network that contains implicit mutual obligations, assurances, and understanding.",
      "aliases": [
        "organizational networking",
        "guanxi hu",
        "social capital in Chinese context"
      ]
    },
    {
      "term": "guanxi_with_business_community",
      "definition": "Horizontal guanxi connections with the task environment of suppliers, buyers, and competitors; interfirm guanxi referring to cross-organizational connections among managers.",
      "context_snippet": "we focus on two distinctive applications of networking skills: horizontal connections with the task environment of suppliers, buyers, and competitors",
      "aliases": [
        "guanxi with competitive forces",
        "horizontal guanxi"
      ]
    },
    {
      "term": "guanxi_with_government_authorities",
      "definition": "Vertical guanxi connections with various levels of government and regulatory agencies, including political governments, industrial departments, taxation bureaus, banks, and industrial and commercial administrative bureaus.",
      "context_snippet": "vertical connections with various levels of government and regulatory agencies",
      "aliases": [
        "guanxi with government",
        "vertical guanxi",
        "guanxi with regulatory authorities"
      ]
    },
    {
      "term": "ownership structure",
      "definition": "Institutional attribute distinguishing state-owned, collectively owned, and privately owned firms; operationalized as a dummy variable with 1 for nonstate-owned firms (collective and private) and 0 for state-owned firms.",
      "context_snippet": "the ownership structure was defined by three groups—state-owned, collectively owned, and privately owned... A dummy variable represented ownership structure, with 1 for nonstate-owned firms",
      "aliases": [
        "state-owned vs nonstate-owned",
        "firm ownership"
      ]
    },
    {
      "term": "location",
      "definition": "Institutional attribute indicating whether a firm operates in an open economic region (designated by the central government to attract investment with incentives and infrastructure) versus a nonopen region; operationalized as a dummy variable with 1 for nonopen cities and 0 for open cities.",
      "context_snippet": "We also created a dummy variable with 1 for nonopen cities and 0 for open cities. Open regions are those areas that the central government has opened to the outside world.",
      "aliases": [
        "open region status",
        "regional openness"
      ]
    },
    {
      "term": "strategic orientation",
      "definition": "A firm’s emphasis on market effectiveness versus operational efficiency; market-oriented strategies (e.g., Prospector/Differentiation) focus on scanning and exploiting new opportunities with high uncertainty, whereas efficiency-oriented strategies focus on stable domains and internal efficiency.",
      "context_snippet": "These strategic configurations all focus on a business’s relative emphasis on market effectiveness vs. operational efficiency... market-oriented firms face a much greater probability of failure and a higher level of outcome uncertainty",
      "aliases": [
        "market-oriented strategy",
        "market effectiveness orientation"
      ]
    },
    {
      "term": "size",
      "definition": "Organizational factor reflecting firm scale; affects structures, culture, access to capital, and need for external ties; measured as total assets.",
      "context_snippet": "We used total assets for firm size... Small firms are more likely to cooperate... Large firms... lack competitive and entrepreneurial mindsets",
      "aliases": [
        "firm size",
        "scale"
      ]
    },
    {
      "term": "technological skills",
      "definition": "Organizational resource reflecting technological competencies enabling new products and processes and adaptation to market dynamics; superior skills reduce external dependence and need for guanxi.",
      "context_snippet": "Technological skills are important for organizational competence... allow for the development of new products and processes",
      "aliases": [
        "technology skills",
        "technological capabilities"
      ]
    },
    {
      "term": "managerial capabilities",
      "definition": "Organizational resource reflecting managerial and organizational skills that are scarce, specialized, tacit, and difficult to imitate or transfer; stronger capabilities reduce reliance on guanxi.",
      "context_snippet": "Managerial skills are important for building organizational competence; they are difficult to imitate because they are scarce, specialized, and tacitly embedded within the firm",
      "aliases": [
        "managerial skills",
        "managerial and organizational skills"
      ]
    },
    {
      "term": "length of operation",
      "definition": "Organizational age measured as number of years operating in China; younger firms face liability of newness and may use guanxi more proactively.",
      "context_snippet": "We used... the number of years operating in China for age... Young organizations are subject to the liability of newness",
      "aliases": [
        "firm age",
        "years of operation"
      ]
    },
    {
      "term": "sales growth",
      "definition": "Performance outcome capturing market expansion over the most recent three years; measured via categorical growth rate ranges.",
      "context_snippet": "We defined performance according to financial measures during the most recent 3 years, i.e., net profit growth and sales growth",
      "aliases": [
        "market expansion"
      ]
    },
    {
      "term": "net profit growth",
      "definition": "Performance outcome capturing growth in net profit over the most recent three years; measured via categorical growth rate ranges.",
      "context_snippet": "We defined performance according to financial measures during the most recent 3 years, i.e., net profit growth and sales growth",
      "aliases": [
        "profit growth"
      ]
    },
    {
      "term": "industry growth index",
      "definition": "Composite indicator at the 2-digit industry level reflecting growth in number of enterprises, net output value, sales revenue, net value of fixed assets, total after-tax profits, and total operating income; computed as the average of compounded annual growth rates over 1993–1995.",
      "context_snippet": "The index reflects multiple aspects of the industry structure... We determine the compound growth rates... used in the following formula to calculate the growth index",
      "aliases": [
        "industry growth",
        "GI"
      ]
    },
    {
      "term": "industry type",
      "definition": "Control variable distinguishing manufacturing versus service industries; coded with a dummy variable (1 for manufacturing; 0 otherwise).",
      "context_snippet": "We utilized a dummy variable to distinguish between manufacturing and service industries... coded 1 for manufacturing industries; 0 otherwise.",
      "aliases": [
        "sector type"
      ]
    }
  ],
  "construct_dimensions": [
    {
      "parent_construct": "guanxi",
      "dimension_construct": "guanxi_with_business_community"
    },
    {
      "parent_construct": "guanxi",
      "dimension_construct": "guanxi_with_government_authorities"
    }
  ],
  "relationships": [

      "boundary_conditions": "Chinese firms operating in China’s transition economy; two applications of guanxi (horizontal with business community and vertical with authorities).",
      "replication_outcome": null,

      "supporting_quote": "Institutional factors (i.e., ownership structure and location) were consistently significant for both horizontally and vertically applied guanxi... Nonstate-owned firms attempt to build connections...",

      "details": "Composite indicator computed from growth rates (1993–1995) of six variables: number of enterprises, net output value, sales revenue, net value of fixed assets, total after-tax profits, and total operating income.",

        "total operating income"

      "scoring_procedure": "Average of compounded annual growth rates across variables",
      "formula": "GI_j = Σ{ [((1 + r_ij,t1)(1 + r_ij,t2)(1 + r_ij,t3))^(1/3) − 1] } / 6",
